column3: question
Explain your logic for game 1
Explain your logic for game 2
Explain your logic for game 3
Player 2 should always accept any offer, even 0 tokens. Any other behavior is just stupid.
Player 2 should always accept any positive offer, though she might reasonably decline the offer of 0 tokens. Any other behavior is just stupid.
Player 2 would normally reject low offers. Most people accept an offer of at least 30 tokens.
Player 2 should reject anything below 50 tokens.
Player 1 should give 50 tokens in any game, aiming for a fair division.
Player 1 has moral right to offer 0 tokens in game 2. There is no shame in doing it.
In game 3, player 1 should give more to player 2 who chose game 1.
In game 3, player 1 should give more to player 2 who chose game 2.
In game 3, the choice of game 1 is a sign of non-cooperative behavior.
Player 1 should give more to player 2 in game 1 if player 2 chose to play that game (as in game 3), as this indicates that player 2 would more likely reject low offers.
Player 1 should give less to player 2 in game 1 if player 2 chose to play that game (as in game 3), to punish player 2.
Player 1 should give more to player 2 in game 2 if player 2 chose to play that game (as in game 3), to reward player 2 for her cooperative behavior.

Player 1 should give less to player 2 in game 2 if player 2 chose to play that game (as in game 3), as this indicates that player 2 understands that the power lies with player 1 in this experiment and player 1 has moral right to offer very little (or even nothing).
Player 2 should choose game 1 because it makes no sense to voluntarily giving up on the opportunity to reject offers.
Player 2 should choose game 1 because she would receive a higher offer by using this strategy.
Player 2 should choose game 2 because he would receive a higher offer by using this strategy.
Player 2 should choose game 2 to signal her trust to player 1.
Player 2 should choose game 2 because it makes no sense to reject offers and everybody understand it.
Player 2 should be more agreeable (accept more offers) in game 1 if he chose to play that game.
Player 2 should be less agreeable (accept less offers) in game 1 if he chose to play that game.
Player 2 should be more agreeable (accept more offers) in game 1 if she chose to play that game because she already have exercised some control over the situation.
Player 2 should be less agreeable (accept less offers) in game 1 if she chose to play that game because by choosing game 1 she warned player 1 of her intent to reject low offers.
Player 2 should expect to get more in game 3 than in game 1.
Player 2 should expect to get less in game 3 than in game 1.
Player 2 should expect to get more in game 3 than in game 2.
Player 2 should expect to get less in game 3 than in game 2.
When playing game 1, it does not make any difference for player 1 whether player 2 chose to play that game (as in game 3) or it was the computer's choice (as in game 1).
When playing game 2, it does not make any difference for player 1 whether player 2 chose to play that game (as in game 3) or it was the computer's choice (as in game 2).

Any amount player 1 offers to player 2 is doubled in size: if player 1 gives x tokens out of 100 tokens to player 2 and the offer is accepted, then player 2 gets 2*x tokens, while player 1 gets 100-x tokens.
Any amount player 1 offers to player 2 is halved: if player 1 gives x tokens out of 100 tokens to player 2 and the offer is accepted, then player 2 gets x/2 tokens, while player 1 gets 100-x tokens.
In game 3, when player 2 chooses game 1 player 1 gets 100 tokens to divide (same as before). However, when player 2 chooses game 2 player 1 gets 200 tokens to divide.
In game 3, when player 2 chooses game 1 player 1 gets 200 tokens to divide; when player 2 chooses game 2 player 1 gets 100 tokens to divide.
Type in any comments you have about the experiment.

column3: Please imagine a ladder, with steps numbered from 0 at the bottom to 10 at the top. The top of the ladder represents the best possible life for you and the bottom of the ladder represents the worst possible life for you. On which step of the ladder would you say you personally feel you stand at this time?
